Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is a single-stranded RNA virus that causes hepatitis A, an acute liver infection. The virus is transmitted through the fecal-oral route, and can be found in the feces of infected people for up to two weeks before and one week after the onset of symptoms.

The body's immune system responds to HAV infection by producing antibodies. There are two types of antibodies that are produced in response to HAV infection: IgM and IgG. IgM antibodies are produced first, and are detectable in the blood within 2-4 weeks of infection. IgG antibodies are produced later, and can persist in the blood for years, providing long-term immunity against HAV infection.

A positive IgG antibody test result indicates that a person has been exposed to HAV and has developed immunity to the virus. A negative IgG antibody test result indicates that a person has not been exposed to HAV or has not developed immunity to the virus.

IgM antibodies, on the other hand, are only detectable for a short period of time after infection. A positive IgM antibody test result indicates that a person is currently infected with HAV. A negative IgM antibody test result does not necessarily mean that a person is not infected with HAV, as the IgM antibodies may have already cleared from the blood.

Normalization of AST and ALT levels is a sign that the liver is recovering from damage caused by HAV infection. However, it does not indicate that the person has developed immunity to the virus.

Vaccination against HAV is the most effective way to prevent HAV infection. The vaccine is given as two doses, 6-12 months apart. The vaccine is safe and effective, and provides long-lasting immunity against HAV infection.

In conclusion, IgG antibody (IgG anti-HAV) is the only option that provides long-term immunity against HAV infection.
